questions.question_text: An engineer is configuring a data policy for IPv4 prefixes for a single WAN Edge device on a site with multiple WAN Edge devices. How is this policy added using the policy configuration wizard?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
Centralized data policies are configured through the Cisco vManage policy wizard. It guides you through four sequential screens that define different parts of the policy construct:

 Create Groups of Interest — At this step, we create lists of interesting items that will later be called in the match or action statements in the policy.
 Configure Traffic Rules — At this point, we specify the match and action conditions.
 Apply Policies to Sites and VPNs — At this step, we associate the policy with a site list and VPNs.

Selected Answer: B
Correct
Given answer is correct "for a single WAN Edge device on a site with multiple WAN Edge devices."
Centralized polycy= B

choices.A: In vBond orchestrator, select the configure --> policies screen, select the localized policy tab, and click add policy.
choices.B: In vManage NMS, select the configure --> policies screen, select the localized policy tab, and click add policy.
choices.C: In vSmart controller, select the configure --> policies screen, select the localized policy tab, and click add policy.
choices.D: In vManage NMS, select the configure --> policies screen, select the centralized policy tab, and click add policy.

discussion.content:
I think B is correct. Higher TLOC preference is chose. C is incorrect since this use VPN 512 (management)
TLOC Preference. Prefer route with highest TLOC preference.
https://www.ciscolive.com/c/dam/r/ciscolive/us/docs/2019/pdf/5eU6DfQV/TECRST-2191.pdf
pag.42
I am quit agree with B!

comments.content: For each TLOC, specify its address, color, and encapsulation. Optionally, set a preference value (from 0 to 232 – 1) to associate with the TLOC address. When you apply a TLOC list in an action accept condition, when multiple TLOCs are available and satisfy the match conditions, the TLOC with the highest preference value is used. If two or more of TLOCs have the highest preference value, traffic is sent among them in an ECMP fashion.
Answer A, due to the fallback requirement

discussion.content:
Option D fulfils the request!

The configuration should not include the management VLAN 512. 
(This VLAN is designated to backhaul traffic via the controllers using DLTS/TLS traffic)
The default action should be to accept

Consequently this eliminates Options A and C to from the answer.
Leaving B and D as options.

The question requires that TLOC MPLS to be preferred and public internet as backup
The preference with the lowest value is chosen within a tloc-list.

To associate with the TLOC address.
When you apply a TLOC list in an action accept condition, when multiple
TLOCs are available and satisfy the match conditions, the TLOC with the lowest
preference value is used. If two or more of TLOCs have the lowest preference
value, traffic is sent among them in an ECMP fashion.

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/routers/sdwan/command/sdwan-cr-book.pdf
{Page 288}
It's B.Admin Vlan is not Management and I think Management VPN (VPN512) doesn't pass on WAN link.
Correct answer is B. Higher TLOC preference is chosen, also VLAN should be 10 and not 512.

comments.content: who said to associate admin vlan to management vlan lol

discussion.content:
as ChrisCCNA's explanation, Admin Vlan = VPN 512.
C is correct

This question has been bugging me for days. I just passed the exam an hour ago and this question was on it. Here's the issue, the given answers here are incorrect I believe its a typo because on the exam the answer was obvious. So here's the correct details to look for: 
Mpls must have the lower priority. TLOC prefers lower.
Action must equal accept in order to 'set' the tloc list
Don't choose the one with NAT fallback or VPN 512
The default action is irrelevant

Answer D I believe is the correct intended answer however I presume "action reject" is a typo. Action Accept is required.

comments.content: Even though, you assume "action accept", but in TLOC list: MPLS preference is 300 and internet is 600, so internet is preferred. D is not corect.

B meets all the requirements, including action accept. 
D has action reject but also has wrong preference. Higher is better. Not sure why you said TLOC prefers lower. See Table 4 on this page:
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/routers/sdwan/configuration/policies/ios-xe-17/policies-book-xe/policy-overview.html

discussion.content: I think this is C. MPLS needs to have a higher preference so that eliminates A and D. Admin traffic hints at VPN 512. There's information about Traffic Engineering in the SDWAN configuration guide 18.4 page 301.

comments.content: Disregard my comment. TLOC preference prefers the lowest value. You cannot include VPN 512 in a data policy. Only "action accept" packets are eligible to be modified by extra parameters.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
No policy config on vSmart. Policies are configured on vManage!

comments.content: vManage has the user interface and accepts the config, but pushes it to vSmart. Therefore the policy is in the vSmart configuration, and surely that is what the question refers to, or the answer to everything would always be vManage, the GUI where everything is configured.

Actually it could go either way, depending on how they mean their wording. They could be referring to the admin using vManage as the config GUI, or they could mean using a policy which resides on vSmart.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
Kind of an awkward question since you can create the centralized control policy on vmanage or vsmart. I still think the correct answer is vsmart since its a centralized control policy being created.

comments.content: Vsmat enforce policies (make it happened, send ot to the edges) the vmanage is the one creating policies, is the one with the data base, and send it to vsmart for the further distrubution to the right devices

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
Q is what does the Admin use...
He uses vManage to create the policy.

Selected Answer: C
All configuration is via vmanage but the question is about where the policy exists.
 So first you need to understand which pilocy should be used to have regional hub topology which is Centralized Policy and it is on vsmart. In case of Localized Policy , it is done through template or CLI which mostly vmanage is responsible.

 
Centralized Policy
The centralized control policy configuration itself remains on the Cisco SD-WAN Controller and is never pushed to local devices.


Localized Policy
Localized policy refers to a policy that is provisioned locally through the CLI on the Cisco IOS XE Catalyst SD-WAN devices, or through a Cisco SD-WAN Manager device template.
I think the key word is 'USE', answer should be vManage

Selected Answer: D
I'll go wih D. You do the configuration on the vManage which then pushes it to vSmart

comments.content:
Also you can google: "where do you create hub and spoke topology cisco sdwan" and the PDF document "Cisco SD-WAN Policy Guide Hub & Spoke Topology" will come up where it says 
"Management plane (vManage): Responsible for central configuration and monitoring.

Control plane (vSmart): Builds and maintains the network topology and makes decisions on where traffic flows."

Exactly, the question is "what does the network administrator use to create a regional hub topology?" and here is your answer vManage is responsible for central Configuration
D is correct answer

discussion.content:
I think the answer is C.
Source (you can also go to the section on control polices and it's all about vSmart too: https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/routers/sdwan/configuration/policies/vedge/policies-book/policy-basics-CLIs.html
C. Control Policy on vSmart , also verified on many other websites

Selected Answer: D
D is the correct answer

Selected Answer: C
The key word here is "USE". We as engineers dont use control policy on vSmart. We can only use vManage to control policies. vManage can then push said policies to vSmart.

Selected Answer: D
take a look --> https://swat-sdwanlab.github.io/mydoc_regional_hub.html

COnfiguration done on vmanage

Mesh

 In the Add Topology drop-down, select Mesh.

 Enter a name for the mesh region policy component.

 Enter a description for the mesh region policy component.

 In the VPN List field, select the VPN list for the policy.

 Click New Mesh Region.

 In the Mesh Region Name field, enter a name for the individual mesh region.

 In the Site List field, select one or more sites to include in the mesh region.

 Click Add.

 Repeat these steps to add more mesh regions to the policy.

 Click Save Mesh Topology.

Selected Answer: D
Centralized policies are configured on vManage and pushed down to vSmart. A centralized control (topology) policy would achieve this, and since the question asks what the admin would use to create the topology, it should be D.

Selected Answer: C
policies are confirgured on vsmart
Correct Answer should be D, vManage send it it to vSmart

questions.question_text: In a customer retail network with multiple data centers, what does the network administrator use to create a regional hub topology?
Which scheduling method is configured by default for the eight queues in the cloud vEdge router?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
By default is 8

"For Cisco vEdge devices, each interface has eight queues, numbered from 0 through 7. Queue 0 is reserved for control traffic, and queues 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6 and 7 are available for data traffic. The scheduling method for all eight queues is WRR. LLQ is not supported."
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/routers/sdwan/configuration/policies/vedge-20-x/policies-book/localized-policy.html#:~:text=The%20default%20scheduling%20method%20for,all%20eight%20queues%20is%20WRR.

answer is A.
For hardware vEdge routers, each interface has eight queues, numbered from 0 through 7. Queue 0 is reserved for low-latency queuing(LLQ), so any class that is mapped to queue 0 must be configured to use LLQ. The default scheduling method for all is weighted roundrobin (WRR).

comments.content: The question says cloud router, which is not a hardware router. Possibly a typo, since it says eight queues.

discussion.content: a Cloud vEdge only ha 4 queues to begin with. Besides that queue 0 is always configured as LLQ, while the remaining ones are WRR

comments.content: In vEdges as you mentioned are only 4 queues but keep in mind that vEdges dont support LLQ, only the cEdges with their 8 queues.
Still, virtual images do not have 8 queues whether they are cisco or viptela

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
cloud-onramp

Correct. Cisco SD-WAN Cloud OnRamp for IaaS extends enterprise WAN to public clouds. 

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/solutions/collateral/enterprise-networks/sd-wan/white-paper-c11-742817.html

Correct. 
- Cisco Software Defined Wide Area Networks (designing, Deploying, and Securing Your Next generation WAN with Cisco SD-WAN) by Joson, Dana Yanch, Dustin Schueman, and John Curran.
Correct.

questions.question_text: In an AWS cloud, which feature provisions WAN Edge routers automatically in Cisco SD-WAN?
